dt: {bc}a stunning, damaging, or shattering effect from a hard blow
{bc}a jarring injury of the brain resulting in disturbance of cerebral function

dt.t: The {wi}concussion{/wi} from the explosion was felt 12 miles away.

pt: {sc}impact{/sc} {sc}collision{/sc} {sc}shock{/sc} {sc}concussion{/sc} mean a forceful, even violent contact between two or more things. {sc}impact{/sc} may be used to imply contact between two things, at least one of which is impelled toward the other.

pt.t: the glass shattered on {it}impact{/it} with the floor

pt: {sc}collision{/sc} implies the coming together of two or more things with such force that both or all are damaged or their progress is severely impeded.
{sc}shock{/sc} often denotes the effect produced by a collision and carries the suggestion of something that strikes or hits with force.
{sc}concussion{/sc} when not in technical use, often suggests the shattering, disrupting, or weakening effects of a collision, explosion, or blow.

pt.t: bystanders felt the {it}concussion{/it} of the blast

et: Middle English {it}concussioun{/it}, from Latin {it}concussion-, concussio{/it}, from {it}concutere{/it} to shake violently, from {it}com-{/it} + {it}quatere{/it} to shake
shortdef: a stunning, damaging, or shattering effect from a hard blow; especially : a jarring injury of the brain resulting in disturbance of cerebral function

dt: {bc}a {d_link|grenade|grenade} that produces its effect by the blast of its detonation rather than from the fragmentation of its casing

shortdef: a grenade that produces its effect by the blast of its detonation rather than from the fragmentation of its casing; also : flash-bang
